channel.title: NYT > Business > Economy
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 The New York Times Company

item.title: Trump’s China Deal May Avert a Crisis of His Own Making
item.description: The Trump administration is hailing a potential deal that may return the U.S.-China relationship to where it was before the president began a trade war against Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Companies Have Shielded Buyers From Tariffs. But Not for Long.
item.description: Cars, toys and tea are among products set to get more expensive as tariffs weigh on corporate profits.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis and Kailyn Rhone

item.title: Trump to Investigate Whether China Abided by 2020 Trade Deal
item.description: The administration announced its trade investigation on Friday, ahead of a summit between U.S. and Chinese leaders.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump Says He’s Cutting Off Trade Negotiations With Canada
item.description: The president said he was motivated by an ad, paid for by the province of Ontario, that featured Ronald Reagan criticizing tariffs in a 1987 radio address.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Matina Stevis-Gridneff

item.title: U.S. to Investigate China’s Compliance With 2020 Trade Deal
item.description: The trade case is coming at a pivotal moment, before a meeting next week between President Trump and China’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Trump’s Sanctions on Russian Oil Sector Ratchet Up Economic War
item.description: After months of restraint, President Trump’s move to blacklist Lukoil and Rosneft will hit Russia where it hurts.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: Oil Prices Dropped 18%, Helping Drivers, but Squeezing the Industry
item.description: Oil prices have fallen sharply this year as the global supply has remained strong and demand has been slow to grow.
item.dc:creator: Rebecca F. Elliott

item.title: The U.S. Struggles to Break Out From China’s Grip on Rare Earths
item.description: The Trump administration is trying an array of unconventional measures to shore up U.S. rare earths supplies. It remains uncertain whether the strategy will work.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Does Your Electric Bill Keep Going Up? We Want to See It.
item.description: Utility rates are rising in many places across the country, and we’re continuing to report on the causes and impacts.
item.dc:creator: Ivan Penn and Rebecca F. Elliott

item.title: How a Long Government Shutdown Could Leave Scars on the Economy
item.description: The effect is rippling beyond missing paychecks to federal services that support much of the economy.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Trump Hopes Argentina Can Help Bring Down Beef Prices
item.description: President Trump’s plan to import red meat runs counter to his philosophy of increasing domestic production, and has angered cattle ranchers in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport

item.title: China’s Rare Earth Restrictions Aim to Beat U.S. at Its Own Game
item.description: Beijing’s latest effort to weaponize global supply chains is modeled on the American technology controls that it has long criticized.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Meaghan Tobin

item.title: Trump’s Trade War With China Catches the World in Its Crossfire
item.description: Tariffs and other restrictions between the United States and China are reverberating in unpredictable ways.
item.dc:creator: Patricia Cohen

item.title: Trump Enacts Tariffs on Imported Lumber and Furniture
item.description: The president is threatening to widen his trade war against China as tariffs on timber, lumber, kitchen cabinets and other products took effect on Tuesday.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson and Sydney Ember

item.title: Black Unemployment Is Surging Again. This Time Is Different.
item.description: Federal layoffs and an end to diversity initiatives have weakened a historically strong labor market for Black workers.
item.dc:creator: Lydia DePillis

item.title: Trump Threatens 100% Tariffs on Chinese Goods
item.description: The president made the threat after Beijing imposed new global restrictions on the use of rare earth minerals, which are vital supplies for U.S. makers of chips and batteries.
item.dc:creator: Ana Swanson

item.title: Inflation Report Will Be Released Despite Shutdown
item.description: The Bureau of Labor Statistics is calling back some employees to produce the Consumer Price Index for September. That data is needed to calculate the annual cost-of-living adjustment for Social Security beneficiaries.
item.dc:creator: Ben Casselman

item.title: Riding the Wild Wave of Crypto Coverage
item.description: David Yaffe-Bellany, a technology reporter who has covered the cryptocurrency industry since 2022, has come to embrace learning on the fly.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Bahr

item.title: Trump Suggests Furloughed Federal Workers May Not Receive Back Pay After Shutdown
item.description: Union leaders and Democratic lawmakers say the move would run afoul of a law adopted under President Trump’s first term.
item.dc:creator: Tony Romm

item.title: Carney and Trump: A Collision Avoided, Save for a Nasty Comment or Two
item.description: The Canadian prime minister came to Washington determined to take the heat out of the relationship. He mostly succeeded, at least for now.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen and David E. Sanger
